commentBody:
Good puzzle but I was struggling with how ‚Äúfourth‚Äù base appears in ‚Äúwrite forth about.‚Äù

Plus I‚Äôm not familiar with that phrase. Speak forth, perhaps?
10A is not a Motown song!

Hi Sam Corbin üòä The hand is a unit of measure of a horse‚Äôs height. I‚Äôm reasonably sure that‚Äôs what the clue is referring to. https://equineworld.co.uk/about-horses/horse-height-measurement/measuring-a-horses-height Mark

Is there a wedding-famous cover of Shout by a Motown artist that I'm not familiar with...?

The Isley Brothers recorded briefly for Motown in the mid/late-60s, but Shout was recorded for RCA Victor. Unless the constructor is using "Motown" as an absorbent genre of any kind of "classic soul" ‚Äì which I am not on board with.
Is the puzzle creator Nathan Hale as in the children's author Nathan Hale?!?!? If so, awesome!

I was "jonesing" for a fun puzzle and got one.
I guess we are celebrating the opening of a new baseball season.
Batter up and have fun!

Enjoyed this very much. Figured out the dashes relatively quickly. Got bogged down in a couple of places (had romeo instead of rodeo for a while) and another typo, but thoroughly enjoyed it and just enough of a challenge for a good brain workout

No idea what's going on with the column, which kept vanishing after a glimpse of it, and the comment I was working on when it finally stopped doing its disappearing act seems to have permanently vanished. Version #2:

The first roadblock I hit in the puzzle had me stymied, so, trusting that I had the right fills, I just thought, Okay, whatever, and pressed on.  About halfway through it became clear that they were CLICHEs that needed a word represented by a(?) black square.  

Otherwise,the puzzle was an easy one, and I did enjoy working it once I just stopped trying to figure out exactly what was going on.  Thank you, Nathan, and congratulations on your newlywed status.  "Hi," to your wife and thank her too.

I liked this one a lot; fun with a well-executed and clean theme/gimmick.

I wonder, though, why this puzzle was slotted on a Wednesday . . . I have done the NYT daily puzzle every day for almost a decade now, and today's sure feels most appropriate for a Thursday...

At any rate, hats off to Mr. Hale :)
Nathan, you really hit it out of the park with this one.

I got the trick even though it was baseball related. However, I've never heard the expressions: GIVE THE (third) DEGREE and WRITE (fourth) ABOUT. Especially the latter looks very weird. Am I missing something? Is the final base not called "fourth" but something else?

In general the puzzle had many more words and expressions unknown to me than usual. On most days trivia stumps me (and sure enough, today I knew neither CASS nor BUC - "buc" is a very rude word in Polish btw), but today it were those two expressions and things like JONESED.

Just wanted to give a little heads up to a new show called Ludwig on Brit Box. 

It is a puzzle person, a big time puzzle person, who has to fill in for his detective twin, who's gone missing... I mean you know standard weird cozy mystery situation, but we enjoyed the first two episodes quite a bit!

Love the puzzle connection!
I actually cruised through this one - might be a wednesday record for me, with no look-ups.   I got the theme early and easy,   Go me!
Mini clue for 4 across is absolutely wrong. IRL is NOT "not online". In fact, there is a category for streamers casting live (I e. "online") called IRL, for In Real Life.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been HAVING THOUGHTS‚Äù mumbled old Dusty.  ‚ÄúIt just seems like this is NOT MY RODEO anymore.  It used to be that the journalists would WRITE ABOUT how exciting our daredevil riding was.  Now the boss just GIVES THE DEGREE of difficulty to them, and no one even bothers to come and watch us ride. They just write a paragraph while hanging out at the bar.‚Äù

His pal Lefty agreed: ‚ÄúYeah, they might as well go write about the baseball game instead. Then at least they would COVER ALL THE BASES.‚Äù
This is a response to Sam Corbin's column.  Hands, as a unit, is a measure of how tall a horse is.  I have no idea why.  It just is.
Bottom left corner was infuriating.
Where‚Äôs HOME? Did I miss it??
I without thought assumed ‚Äúbases‚Äù meant numeral systems (binary, decimal, etc.) and spent a few seconds wondering what number one writes about. Oh yes, time for another sport season.
Hand or "Muzham" is (was)  a unit of measurement in Tamil Nadu, India. Mostly used in villages or by farmers. Length from the tip of elbow to tip of the middle finger.

Eminently do-able, and enjoyable, with absolutely no idea that there was a baseball connection!
When you have a phrase like BEER ME (is that really real?) then NOT MY RODEO and HAVING THOUGHTS just seem like more odd Americanisms. 
I always thought COVER ALL THE BASES had a military connection. Like cover with camouflage.
I only had trouble with PBR (I know Stella is a lager) IRA, RBI (something to do with boxing?) and LLCS.
Thank you! :D I am glad the glitch was fixed.
An IRA is not a ‚ÄúPortfolio holding‚Äù. It is an account in which those ‚Äúholding(s)‚Äù are kept.

Got this one pretty quickly this morning! I plugged in "NOTMY RODEO" right away and figured out the clue. I had some trouble in the bottom left corner, I can never remember if it's RPI or RBG or RBO or whatever that baseball stat is üò≠ü§£

Really fun puzzle.

Time was, I would be
jonesing for sativa!

Fun days.
Loved the reminder.

And it‚Äôs my birthday!

So I‚Äôm gonna party like‚Ä¶

it‚Äôs a middle-aged lady‚Äôs birthday
on a Wednesday.

Falafel pita and vodka spritzer.
Bed by 9:00!

Woohoo!

Happy hump day all!
When did cannabis varieties become general knowledge?

Fun puzzle and a good workout. Took me a while to catch on to the trick and... a dim-witted moment was when I was pondering 'fourth' at 63/64 across. And yeah, I'm a baseball fan. duh. One puzzle find today was inspired by the constructor's name. A Sunday from February 25, 2018 by Will Nediger with the title: "Letter recycling." The trick in that one was pairs of across and down answers that crossed each other and each of which used the same letters. One example was: ETHANALLEN crossing NATHANHALE A couple of others: OUTSTANDING/ASTOUNDING PISTACHIOS/POTATOCHIPS IRONAGE/GEORGIANERA Don't recall seeing another one like that. Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/25/2018&g=28&d=A I'm done. ...
Yaaay, my puzzle looks "right" today!!!!!!  Thank you

I tried to comment last night, but the comments were glitching like the desktop puzzle was yesterday morning. Judging by when the first comment posted, the comments were finally fixed around 1 am ET. 

At which point, it was actually only one day before Opening Day. Which makes me wonder, why wasn‚Äôt this run on actual Opening Day? Was it deemed not tricky enough for a Thursday?

Of course, by now I‚Äôve mostly forgotten what I was going to say last night,,,except:

Play ball!

(Note to newer solvers: It always pays to reflect on what day it is‚Ä¶not just the day of the week, but if there are any special events on the day or imminently.)
If you‚Äôre old hat, you know 37A should run for the start of the NBA season instead. Basketball Jones: https://tinyurl.com/3kc375nw
Are the bases supposed to be arranged in the grid like on a baseball diamond? I can't see it. Or am I trying too hard?
This was fun.  For longer than I should have, I wondered why I hadn't heard of the popular wedding song, "Shoot."

There have baseball-bases-based themes in puzzles before, but not like this.  This is a new wrinkle, and props to Nathan for his originality.  

You would think that at some point, all the crossword themes would be used up and we‚Äôd be going into reruns.  But no, no hint of that happening.  The creativity of the crossword creators shows no sign of abating, and our quirky language seems to have an infinite capacity for wordplay.  Crosslandia, the gift that keeps on giving.

Also, props to Nathan for finding theme answers that not only are gold ‚Äì lively and interesting ‚Äì but also, remarkably, fit the requirements of symmetry.  Wow to that.

Lovely serendipities abounded: BIC crossing BUC, semordinaps BUC and CUB, TWO crossing the second base answer, and PuzzPair¬© BERET / OLD HAT.  Plus, words I love SPRIG, VISAGE, and HOOCH. 

A bright start to the day, and that‚Äôs a gift.  Thank you for making this, Nathan!
A fun one - smooth other than a brief hitch in the SW as I had to get ABRAM from the crosses. So off to do my homework!: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abraham

Pet peeve alert:
Traditionally, the answer to 1-down was not used as an adjective, only as a noun. But I realize this battle was lost long ago.

I liked this puzzle. It was fun and interesting, My only hangup was with the name of the fictional moon. I saw the movie but do I  remember the name of the moon? Nope. I also had no idea what 32 across meant so that made a nasty natick, but overall really a nice puzzle.

Fairly straight forward, definitely fun. A few unknowns as usual; I‚Äôve heard the term JONESED from US tv shows, without actually understanding what it meant, so thanks for that.

TIL BEER ME is an actual thing, thanks to @Bruce for the explanation below. Explaining to DH that people actually throw beer cans/bottles to each other earned a frown and a tut. We expect a head on our beer when poured, chucking it about would result in all head (froth) no beer. Definitely not cricket.
Horses are measured in hands.
Turned out to be my fastest Wednesday, but I really wanted it to go on for longer... Very nice puzzle and clever theme, thanks Nathan!
Ya hit it out of the park, Nathan...a cracker-jack of a Wednesday puzzzle!

What a great, fun puzzle! Really enjoyed the trick that was made accessible through the idioms being so familiar. Have to admit I finished the puzzle still wondering about the O-Neg answer, so was glad to see that addressed in the column here! :)

Another travel-related solve, this one at a hallucinatory early hour in the hell that is Heathrow airport.
I know just enough about baseball to get the theme very quickly (and to know that "fourth" gets you HOME.
One natick for me, at the cross between unknown abbreviations in 49D and 59A. Picture my delight, as I settled down to run the alphabet in order, to get a hit on A!

CLICHE as an adjective still makes me wince, having been brought up on clich√© as the noun and clich√©d as the adjective. But of course it actually works fine as a participle adjective, being the past participle of French clicher, to copy or stereotype. Yet still I wince, for no defensible reason.
Pedantically speaking, ONEG is an exact constant (of acceleration, not force) and not what I would call informal.

My personal pot Portuguese natick kept this from being a personal best.

 But it was a fun romp around the bases

Great puzzle. From 1A on, I felt comfortable with it. The theme was clever, fun, and above all, not hellishly difficult to figure out. Even the unfamiliar items had crossing words that helped. 
I only had to look up one term in the SE corner.

Congratulations to Nathan Hale! (Did not know he was still active.)

Let's all hope Nathan has more than one puzzle to give for his country...er, fans!

Right off, let me confess I went hook, line, and sinker for the 4th themer, so of course IRL was my last entry thanks to my state of confusion.  
Other than that, the only source of confusion was the 3D/31A crossing.  I cry Natick here.  I think having to learn more Portuguese than S√ÉO is unfair.  And varieties of pot?  Come now.

Mr. Hale has had a previous puzzle in the NYT, but has not submitted a photo, which I think should be mandatory.  Does he wear his hair in a queue, ala the late 1700's?  Perhaps a tricorne?  
Is he young or old?  Hath he the SLY VISAGE of a fox? Or a lean and hungry look?  Inquiring solvers want to know...

You know what they say:

Small hands, big horse.

My daughter went to Iowa State.  Of her three besties, one was from Minnesota, one Texas and one Illinois.  (She also has tons of friends actually from Iowa.)

Fun puzzle though!

When I was a student in the '70s, I knew many slang terms for marijuana -- pot, weed, ganja, reefer. herb, mary jane -- but the most amusing one for nerd smokers was to call it by its Latin name, Cannabis SATIVA.

Years later, when industrious pot-heads (is that an oxymoron?) were pushing for legalization, I learned that there were other species of Cannabis, and that many of this country's founding fathers grew Cannabis on their plantations, claiming that it was used for hemp and rope-making.  It was intimated that they sometimes filled their pipes with the crop.

I hope this story is true.
Shout is not a Motown song!   The Isley Brothers were briefly signed to the company but that was years after the song‚Äôs release on RCA in 1959.

After progressing through the first three bases, I was ready to take her (home) to mother. 

Who is Emily (44D) and why is she in Paris? I've seen better clues for BERET. Nice to see TERI Polo again; she's a local girl.
Horse "hand" measurement is 4 inches and I don't remember why I know that.
A horse "hand" measurement is 4 inches and I don't remember why I know that.
Solved this (delightful) puzzle, then sat for a minute wondering why I‚Äôd never heard the idiom ‚ÄúWRITE FOURTH ABOUT‚Äù before the truth dawned on me. I‚Äôm sports savvy, I swear!
Happy baseball season to all! Love this puzzle to pieces.

If the constructor were a regular commenter here, he would surely have dedicated this puzzle to Steve L, our in-house baseball aficionado who tries and tries to make us HIP TO the game. So far, I've only committed to memory RBI, but thanks for trying, Steve! Despite my rudimentary notion of the game, I was able to COVER ALL THE BASES of this puzzle with no problem, though before I figured out the trick, I had "HAVING cold feet" which fit perfectly. Figuring it out put a smile on my face. Loved it! Yet again, a puzzle that leaves me in awe of constructors' imagination and ingenuity. Thank you for a superb romp, Mr. Hale! Others here have pointed out having a natick at the crossing of SATIVA and ELA. It wasn't the case for me. I have no idea why I know SATIVA; then again, I have no idea about any of the other kinds of pot. And ELA came easily, what with Portuguese being my second fluent language, but I did wonder how my fellow solvers were expected to know that. On that note, here is the bossa nova great Tom Jobim with "ELA √© Carioca" (carioca is the term for a native of Rio de Janeiro, coming from the indigenous Tupi language "kari'oka", meaning "house of the white man"): https://youtu.be/tiMpPVDLhgc?si=rysYsIeHbHGcHP0F

I'm a baseball fan - look at my avatar. Go, Red Sox! (Love that dirty water...)
Enjoyed the puzzle. I like how Nathan worked CUB, RBI, and DIV in there. Surprised he didn't use "Pittsburgh MLBer" for 24D, in keeping with the baseball theme.
PS Thank you NYT games for fixing the format glitch from yesterday.

I‚Äôm rather intrigued by the objections to
‚Äúbeer me‚Äù today.

The queen knighted Richard today.
She knighted him.
They feted the Oscar winners today.
They feted them.
They crowned the derby winner today.
They crowned her.

Nominal verb with object. Applaud me. Sing me. Lullaby me. Beer me. Tequila me. King me. Queen me.

English is a beautiful and fluid language. Only English teachers stand in its way and clip its beautiful wings.

Any other dumb dumbs frivolously try and make FOURTH fit in the final themed clue? 

Hit a HOME run in the end, but that had me questioning everything I knew before it finally clicked lmao. 

Fairly easy Wednesday all said and done, but a super fun puzzle and generous clueing. Thanks Nathan.
Hope I'm not the only one to ponder what "write fourth about" means before getting it and feeling silly Lol

Lots of junk today. ELA DIV WAS IRL RBI PBR BAS. Consequently a slow solve and not much fun.

The theme was good. A massive pity the bases could not be arranged in an approximately diamond shape.
So fun, Nathan!
I'm delighted to see such solidarity among the (many) solvers who tried to make "write fourth about" happen. I just dropped in to say that. Write forth in the comments!
https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/25/well/mind/brain-games-cognitive-decline-memory.html?unlocked_article_code=1.6k4.UXRR.wpGibvlt91ou&smid=url-share
Such a clever theme. Lots of fun to solve. Thanks Nathan üòä
You measure horses in hands. An 5-second google search would have told the writer this.

Took me about ten minutes to see the theme. Very clever!  And timely! LGM!!

As to the fourth/home thing, I know that idiom mainly as a negative, like "Ah, nothing to write home about." I've ever seen it used as, say, "Now that's something to write home about!"
Clever puzzle with the dashes. I appreciate that for this hump day.

Would have been a smooth solve until I hit the lower left part.  Could not figure out how to make fourth work for the minus part.  Broke down and googled Corbyn's name and that didn't help either.  Didn't help that I had no idea what the pre-covenant biblical name meant.  And the Time clue was no help, had "out" for the answer for awhile.  Finally completed with write fourth about even though it didn't make sense.  I don't like baseball but that is no excuse.  Sheesh.  Palm to forehead.

Great job Nathan! I love when there‚Äôs a theme even if the words/answers aren‚Äôt necessarily highlighted. I wasn‚Äôt even doing the down clues yet, but I figured the answer/word was VELVET and I immediately thought of George from Seinfeld. Great minds must think alike!! Namaste my fellow NYTers and have a Wonderful Wednesday!!!

I have to remember that the people who construct crosswords have very little knowledge about much of anything except crossword puzzles and to avoid playing them if there is anything else I can possibly do to occupy myself.

I liked this puzzle. Only real hangup I had was lower left. ‚ÄúTime ____‚Ä¶‚Äù could be anything, why is this WAS?! I also tried to put OOO before realizing they wanted IRL. 

As someone else noted, SHOUT is not Motown. Poor research.

Clever Wednesday offering, and not so easy for me. Not familiar with JONESED and can never remember IRL. Knowing JEREMY and ABRAM helped in the SW corner. PAMPHLETS and VISAGES are interesting words. Enjoyed this one.

I, too, am HIPTO YAMS!  

Nathan Hale's debut (January '24) is a favorite of mine, so I was glad to see his name again. This was another fun one! Always love the aha moment when I get the theme, and this was a good one. 

Apparently, however, after today and yesterday, I best start getting HIPTO more cannabis varieties....  Here I am, like... "Uh, there are different varieties...!?" No problem getting them on crosses but I'd be more familiar with HOOCH varieties, I'd say. 

And though I'm not much for beer, I would be REMISS to not mention that lovely crossing of PBR and BEERME! Now that's something to WRITE ‚Äî ABOUT.
NYT, Sam Corbin: In Great Britain ‚Äúhands‚Äù is the standard of measure for the height of a horse.
Fun theme and a perfect Wednesday difficulty. Just a small gripe with time WAS, which felt ambiguous to me.
I have a BONE to pick, not a NOSE...

It‚Äôs been a long long time since I‚Äôve done an early week puzzle.  (You know, because imma genius that can‚Äôt be wasting my time on no ez puhzuls). 

I‚Äôm glad I picked today to do one. 
Very fun. And way to make Wednesday pop. 

Thank you
Come on editors. Should have left the original 39D clue...
AFK is modern shorthand for not online. IRL is like touching grass.
Absolutely wonderful. Well done. Just a perfect theme and a perfect Wednesday puzzle.
Lovely!
the height of horses is measured in hands....
Play ball! ‚öæÔ∏è üß¢ üèüÔ∏è  YAAAAAAAY Opening Day (tomorrow)! Go O's!

Late to the party today!
Another instance where saving the revealer to the last paid off--got the gimmick of the missing {FIRST}, {SECOND}, and {THIRD}, but what does WRITE {FOURTH} ABOUT signify?
And then --Aha!
What a fun puzzle to come home at the end of stressful week at work! Thank you, Mr. Hale!

25A was interesting to me. While I understand  HAVING and what it means to have or not have something, I am missing connection between the clue and the answer. To have or not have a wedding... But as clued I wanted to answer with Hawing (ie, to hem and haw about something). Fun puzzle, but welcome some enlightenment on 25A.
Yep, today's puzzle certainly hit a home run with me... (and I agree with Sam on 41D... took me a moment to realize what the answer was saying)
I‚Äôd confess that I spent a few minutes trying to decipher WRITE FOURTH ABOUT, but that would make me look foolish.
Can someone explain ‚Äúsleep with‚Äù and ‚Äúbed‚Äù? Why is the ‚Äúwith‚Äù there?

Since I assume he‚Äôs not the 18th century spy, does anyone know if this Nathan Hale is the same person who writes historical graphic novels for kids? Check them out if you have young people around, my kids are huge fans!
Nice puzzle. Once again I finished it before I figured out the gimmick. I did, at least, figure it out (unlike some others).
Not a fan of this one.  I couldn't get with the theme and the four "-" clues made no sense to me.  On to Thursday!

Enjoyed picking up on the theme about 75% of the way through and using it to solve the puzzle. The worst is when I quickly understand the theme but still can‚Äôt finish the entire puzzle, looking at you Sunday.
Not knowing baseball I was looking to fill in with a fourth base.

Rave over, metaphorically = WRITE?

‚ÄúTime _____ ‚Ä¶‚Äù = WAS?

Other than this nasty crossing I found this entire puzzle particularly easy for a Wednesday.  Always frustrating when a single clue or crossing guns up the works.
I figured out the theme soon enough. But was looking to COVER a FOURTH base
‚ÄúHackneyed‚Äù is an adjective and despite some popular misuse ‚Äúcliche‚Äù is a noun (still) so the answer here should surely be ‚Äúcliched‚Äù?

I hate gimmick puzzles so much. I wish there was a standard crossword daily and these could be in a separate section for the people who enjoy them.

At least label them so they could be more easily skipped.
@Paul  ‚Äúhome‚Äù
@Paul I thought the same, and then it hit me...home plate/base. WRITE (HOME) ABOUT.
@Paul home plate, not fourth base üòä

@Paul 

Took me a minute, and baseball has been a part of my life forever.
@Paul   I couldn't figure out why the baseball kept getting bigger.   Then it hit me.

@Charlie 

Wasn‚Äôt that last week‚Äôs puzzle? (You were playing the Astros.)
@Greg Tormo Yes. Originally recorded in NYC.
@Jack Agree.

@Miriam   I thought we were supposed to remember him for saying  "I regret that I have but one life to lose for my country".    Before being hanged by the British for being an American patriot-spy.   Statue of him at Yale.   Did he also write children's books?   Or are we up to three Nathans now?    Perhaps other commenters will know of more to add to the list...
Nathan Hale was also the protagonist of the brilliant Resistance and Resistance 2 shooter games on Playstation 3.
@Miriam There is a Nathan Hale high school in Seattle. Pretty sure it's not named after the crossword creator or the children's author :)
@Min Agreed!
@Megan - I can see various occasions where "not my first romeo" could come up!  In fact, it's a great variant.
@Megan   "Not my first Romeo" is hilarious.   I'm surprised that's not already used in forums discussing online dating.

Dave,

I am surprised that after almost a decade of daily solving you are surprised to see a mildly tricky puzzle like this one show up on a Wednesday.
@Dave Definitely not a Thursday-level puzzle IMHO. Fun Wednesday puzzle!

@Dave 

Based on my completion time, I wouldn't have run this on a Thursday.  My time was much closer to my Tuesday average, than my Wednesday average.
@Andrzej In baseball the fourth base is called home.

@Andrzej 

i can see how all of those would be difficult if not american imo. thanks for calling them out. i wouldn‚Äôt expect anyone internationally to know ‚Äújonesing‚Äù

@Andrzej 

Nothing to write home about is like saying no big deal. 

Hey, how was your trip? 

Well, it was fine but nothing to write home about.....

Does that make sense?

@Andrzej 

Nothing to write home about is like saying no big deal. 

Hey, how was your trip? 

Well, it was fine but nothing to write home about.....
 
So, though I haven't really heard about it, I guess the opposite would be something to write home about.... 

It's a little bit of a stretch for me too because I only ever heard in the negative. 

As usual, that's all I got!  ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

@HeathieJ 

Not sure how I showed up twice here with an incomplete response than a complete response, but the emus move and mysterious ways.
@Andrzej   I'll agree with you; as in Heather J's sample setence, the expression is used almost exclusively in the negative.

@Andrzej   Yeah, I don't know if you looked this up already, or it's interesting to you, or helpful, but the team name is the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.   Which gets shortened to "The Bucs" - always plural.   And a buccaneer, of course, is another name for a pirate.
@David And technically, it's not a base, but a plate.

@Andrzej on ‚Äúthe third degree‚Äù. It‚Äôs an American idiom which means severe questioning to get a confession typical to the police‚Ä¶close to torture‚Ä¶in the old movies it‚Äôs where they shine the overhead lightbulb right in the accused face.

It‚Äôs one of those idioms so ingrained in the American film noir psyche we don‚Äôt even think about where it comes from.   It appears to come from severe questioning one would get as they tried to level up to the third level of freemasonry‚Ä¶and was eventually transferred to NYC police work.
Andrzej, The positive may be the original, but for the most part only the negative is in use today. https://wordhistories.net/2019/02/03/write-home-about/

@Andrzej I believe the clue is referencing the phrase that you are familiar with. "Nothing to write home about" is the same as saying "Nothing to rave over."

So "WRITE (HOME) ABOUT" is equivalent to "Rave over."

@W johnson Actually, technically, it's home base. 2.02 Home Base Home base shall be marked by a five-sided slab of whitened rubber. It shall be a 17-inch square with two of the corners removed so that one edge is 17 inches long, two adjacent sides are 8¬Ω inches and the remaining two sides are 12 inches and set at an angle to make a point. It shall be set in the ground with the point at the intersection of the lines extending from home base to first base and to third base; with the 17-inch edge facing the pitcher‚Äôs plate, and the two 12-inch edges coinciding with the first and third base lines. The top edges of home base shall be beveled and the base shall be fixed in the ground level with the ground surface. https://img.mlbstatic.com/mlb-images/image/upload/mlb/atcjzj9j7wrgvsm8wnjq.pdf It's more commonly called home plate, but not in the rule book. For those of you who are unaware, the other bases are soft and raised above ground, while home is a hard rubber slab that is flush with the ground.

@Andrzej 

My husband and I do the CW together most mornings and check the comments after.  We always love reading your perspective on the English language and American culture, especially in these crazy times.  You have our deep respect.  Keep the comments coming!

@Shauron 

üëçüèæ

@Andrzej 

I'm one of those who is interested in you Polish solving experience, and, frankly, I'm not sure why I am.
I suspect that it's because I want to understand better the confusion of non-native speakers in improving their "American English".

I might add that I'm nothing but frustrated when I see Brits post about the incorrect use of language in these puzzles.
I suspect that's because I don't want to hear them lecturing us about the "proper" use of English.
[The "LEGOS" debate is a good example of this.]

@Andrzej 

To be more complete, it's home plate

And if you think about it, when you run around the bases. When you've completed the diamond - you're back where you started home sweet home.

This is where home run 
and homer (slang for home run) come from.

@Andrzej 

I liked your comment on why you should be proud of being Polish when you had no choice on where you were born.

I've *always* felt that way about any "pride" of belonging to a group purely by definition.  I never felt any real pride in being American, and right now I feel a distinct shame about being American.

Likewise with "school spirit".  Or state spirit, like "I'm from  Colorado, the best state of the 50".

@The X-Phile 
I hope I haven't implied that US English is 'incorrect' but I am interested in the use of language, especially because (or since?) US usage does tend to drift over to us (See 'You're welcome' I mentioned earlier, a completely new practice since I was young).

@Mr Dave 

Bottom line is - I come here for the puzzles and the comment board. There is nothing wrong with the column - I'm simply not interested in it. However, ever since I went online for the first time almost 30 years ago, I've enjoyed conversing with people from all around the world. I think it's brilliant I can rely on Americans to explain stuff to me, and me personally. I have my favorite online media on which I rely for news and columns - and the NYT is not it.

It's also a measuremen of the size of a horse.  One hand equals four inches, and the measurement is taken from the ground to the withers (the highest point of the horse's shoulders).
@Raj - the word for that measurement is cubit. The cubit is six palms with each palm being four fingers wide (6 hands). A royal cubit had seven palms.

@Raj 

It was a measurement in Poland for centuries, too, but over here it was called "≈Çokieƒá", elbow. It was used mostly by cloth traders.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

"Beer me" is real.

You call it to a person across the room, generally, and they toss it to you underhanded (while it's still unopened in its bottle or can, if course).

You get extra points if you catch it one-handed, and even more if you do so without looking up.

Some people look down on this practice as being boorish. It's one of those unbridgable cultural divides, I guess.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

RBI is a baseball stat- runs batted in. A good hitter is called a slugger , I can see how it might seem like a boxing thing. I find it fascinating to see the challenge these American expressions pose for solvers in other countries. Maybe I should try a British puzzle!

@Jane Wheelaghan "Beer me" goes back well over three decades, as evidenced in this episode of the American sitcom "Parker Lewis Can't Lose" from 1992. https://youtu.be/Gj1qlrbu4tU?si=r-u1h3IqF7G4AJvf&t=866 After he says "beer me," Parker says "Brewski number two-ski." This was until quite recently my white whale of pop-culture reference that I pursued over the internet sea without success for a long time. Last week it was happily found, and with it, "beer me" evidence to boot, which came in handy today!

@Jane Wheelaghan 

To add to Ron‚Äôs reply:

A slugger is a power hitter. He hits the ball hard and far. While some batters‚Äô job is primarily to get on base, a slugger‚Äôs job is to bring those runners home. So generally, the slugger is not first but rather third through fifth in the lineup. 

An RBI is any run scored as a result of a hit (or sacrifice fly, described recently in these comments) or even an out by the batter (including his own, if he hits a home run).

Hope this didn‚Äôt get too complicated to be helpful.
"Beer Me" was popular enough to have been featured on The Simpsons in 1989

@Bruce 
Thanks for that. I too was wondering if it was a real thing. Can‚Äôt say I‚Äôve ever heard it either in a pub or party. No one would thank you if you threw an unopened bottle of beer here, the resulting explosion would win you no friends!

@Jane Wheelaghan 

An LLC is a limited liability company. It, in some ways, bridges the gap between a sole proprietor or a partnership and a corporation in that if the company goes under your personal assets (like your house, your car, your investments, etc) won't be seized in order to pay off the company's debts.

PBR is short for Pabst Blue Ribbon,  which is an an inexpensive beer favored by working-class folks and college students. It's place in our culture is perfectly illustrated by a line in David Lynch's "Blue Velvet," which I unfortunately cannot quote here.

I'm kind of a beer snob, but I won't turn down a cold PBR.

An IRA is an Individual Retirement Account, and is intendted as a way to provide individuals with a method for saving for retirement that has tax advantages.

@Steve L

After the Ohio Teachers' Retirement Fund went bankrupt for the 4th time, I was rather anxious, esp since my career was interrupted by motherhood (not the usual 'back-to-work in 6 weeks' scenario; our first child had serious medical problems).  I withdrew the (paltry) money and put it into an IRA when those came along.  I wish I could take credit, but it was DHubby who was sure it was a good idea.  That was about 40 years ago, and it was indeed smart.  (Later a Roth IRA was an even better thought.)  I'm now in the RMD phase, where I am Required to take at least some portion of the savings out (a Minimum Distribution) each year.  I ultimately re-entered the workforce after 20 years, but between miserably low pay and health iinsurance premiums, there wasn't much 'retirement savings' to speak of.  I really wish teachers had been part of Social Security.  (I have a Poverty Level Soc Sec benefit from part-time work I did over the years.)

@Mean Old Lady lowercase g, as used here, is the gravitational acceleration at a point on the surface of the earth and is usually equal to about 9.81 m/s^2. 1g, thus, is one times the constant g, and can be substituted into Newton‚Äôs F=m*a to find (for example) a force resisting the gravitational acceleration at Earth‚Äôs surface. Again, pedantic, but as an engineer that‚Äôs my job‚Ä¶

Andrew,

"Informally" is often used in crossword clues when the answer is or contains an abbreviation or shortening of a word or term. G -- properly g, but no lower case in the grid -- as in ONEG is not informal, but as a representation it is definitely shorter than "standard acceleration due to gravity."

@Mean Old Lady a "G" is a unit equal to the gravitational force of the Earth. So when an astronaut or a pilot or race-car driver says they've experienced "6 Gs" it means they were subjected to 6 times the Earth's gravity.

@Mean Old Lady 
Capital G is the Universal Gravitational Constant, which need not detain us. Lower-case g is the acceleration due to gravity, 9.8m/s/s, or 32ft/s/s.
To derive force, you need to multiply g by the mass being accelerated.
So I think vaguely and inaccurately describing g as a "force" is what counts as "informal" usage, here.

@Mean Old Lady I had a college classmate named SATIVA. Her parents were children of the 60s and the result was that I learned a new word that stuck with me to this day. I don't know any Portuguese but I've now seen enough in xword puzzles to know that it is basically abbreviated Spanish.

@sotto voce 

I did actually walk to school all 6 years of grade school, and it was about a mile, and in the snow and dark and rain in the appropriate seasons. Only not barefooted! In the rain we wore rubbers over our school shoes, yes, they were called rubbers. In the winter, we were dressed akin to Ralphie's brother in A Christmas Story in snow pants and sweater and winter coat over our school clothes along with hat, gloves and scarves. Our poor teachers peeled off the layers at our arrival and did the reverse before we trekked home. Imagine matching up all that gear to the correct kid...ah yes, time was...

I worked for six years with a man of Brazilian Indian heritage who hailed from the Amazon. He and his brothers would row a canoe to school every day, some five miles. It was truly inspiring how he came to leave the Amazon, learn English, and finding his way to having a diplomatic service visa in Washington, D.C.
